Award.AwardTitle: PRISM: CSUSB Strengthening the Scientific Workforce
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will strengthen the scientific workforce by increasing the number of well-prepared graduates in STEM disciplines. It will attract promising students to STEM disciplines through an early research experience, retain PRISM scholars through mentoring and advising, and incorporate them into the scientific community at large. The intellectual content of this project is substantial. Lasting partnerships between faculty in Chemistry, Computer Science, Geology, Mathematics and Physics will be developed as a result of this project. For five summers scholars will be recruited for a research experience, which will be followed by an extensive mentoring and advising process for the duration of their undergraduate careers. The summer research component will engage PRISM scholars in a three-week residential early research experience. Each partner discipline will offer a project designed by experienced faculty mentors to introduce scholars to the excitement of scientific discovery and the centrality of mathematics in applied fields. Participants will actively engage in research, developing effective teamwork and communication skills while being inspired to persevere in the pursuit of a scientific career. The residential aspect of the program, together with social activities, will develop the kind of peer-support group that is critical to continued success. Academic year research will be supported by the program, taking advantage of scholars' new-found enthusiasm for the sciences. Every effort will be made to not just retain scholars, but to have them succeed. Following the initial research component, PRISM scholars will undergo rigorous advising and mentoring. Scholars will meet quarterly with advisors to discuss course selection, current coursework, and academic/career opportunities. As a result of this program's partnerships with several existing programs, PRISM scholars will participate in five Career Education Workshops, a Science Networking and Recruiting Forum, workshops on research and graduate school opportunities, and GRE preparation courses. These mentoring and advising activities will ensure greater retention of PRISM scholars, and increased incorporation into the scientific community. Curricular changes include developing a non-calculus introductory course in mathematics, as well as a minor in Applied Mathematics. The curricular changes, mentoring activities, interdisciplinary partnerships and student research experiences combine to create a vibrant intellectual atmosphere that will effectively prepare PRISM scholars for scientific careers.

This program will significantly enhance the development of a scientific workforce, and have a lasting impact on the scientific community at large. Committed to the principle of diversity, this program aggressively recruits from the diverse student population at CSUSB, a Hispanic-Serving and Minority Institution. PRISM scholars will positively influence area high schools and STEM disciplines at CSUSB through presentations and leadership roles on campus, as well as the broader scientific community through presentations, subsequent research, internships, and ultimately career choices. Hence this program will expose a large population of those underrepresented in the sciences to the excitement of scientific endeavor, and will significantly enhance human resource development by producing well-trained and better-prepared young scientists. PRISM scholars will also continue to contribute to the scientific community for years to come. By graduation, they will already be active community members through conference participation, being leaders in their local communities, and producing research that furthers knowledge in Chemistry, Computer Science, Geology, Math, and/or Physics. As PRISM scholars mature in their chosen careers this influence will only continue to grow, indicating that the potential impact of this program on the sciences is truly significant. Further, the program has an aggressive plan for broad dissemination in order to enhance scientific understanding. Avenues for dissemination include the program's website, support to present at conferences, publication when appropriate, as well as sharing best practices, developed lab/course materials, and educational advances. The activities and research resulting from this program, then, will well serve the broader framework of the scientific community at large.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PRISM program at California State University, San Bernardino, had a three-fold purpose.  Our goals were to recruit students to pursue undergraduate degrees in STEM disciplines, retain students in those disciplines throughout their undergraduate careers, and incorporate them into the scientific community.  As a result, the PRISM program was designed to create a cohort of well-prepared young scientists who significantly impact more technical fields for years to come.

The PRISM program used a multi-pronged approach to achieve these goals.  This began with a preparatory math course using high-impact practices to introduce students to the foundational nature of mathematics in scientific research and to foster peer relationships through active group-based learning strategies.  This course was followed by an intensive three-week residential research experience that served to introduce students to discipline-specific research skills as well as develop confidence in their ability to conduct research.  Additionally, students worked closely in small groups with a faculty mentor.  This experience furthered the fostering of peer relationships begun during the preparatory math course, and began the development of faculty-student mentor relationships that would continue throughout their undergraduate career.  During subsequent years, PRISM scholars were provided with opportunities to further incorporate themselves into the scientific community.  These ranged from seminars on how to find an internship or summer research program, to support for conference travel or academic year research.  Faculty-student mentor relationships grew as PRISM scholars relied more heavily on their mentors for advice and information regarding their chosen fields, and the cohorts developed during the summer helped provide the peer network that scholars need to be successful in their upper division coursework and future research.  These strategies were employed by the PRISM program to prepare PRISM scholars for careers in STEM disciplines.

The intellectual merit and broader impacts of the program are now discussed, followed by a brief summary of data indicating the success of the program.  The summer research projects form the basis of the intellectual merit of the PRISM program.  Students were recruited into one of Chemistry, Computer Science, Geology, Math or Physics, to conduct research.  Faculty mentors experienced with undergraduate research developed projects in each field, and each project underscored the importance of mathematics and mathematical thinking to research in the field.  Since PRISM scholars were mostly first- or second-year students the subject matter was, for the most part, not advanced enough for scholarly publication, although the Geology group did publish their results.  Further indication of the intellectual merit of our program is the fact that 37% of our scholars conducted research beyond the PRISM summer experience, and 39% of them attended scientific conferences and/or presented their results.  Thus the continuing involvement of our scholars in scientific pursuits, and the summer projects themselves, point to the strength of the science conducted in the PRISM program.

In addition to producing significant scientific work, the PRISM program at CSUSB has had a broad influence indeed.  The summer research component has had an immediate impact on 161 scholars, training them in the techniques of their chosen discipline.  Nearly one-third of PRISM scholars were involved in mentoring or leadership roles on campus, impacting the University community as a whole.  Scholar presentations and continued research, mentioned above, attest to the fact that the PRISM program has had an impact on the broader scientific community as well.  A survey of PRISM graduates was conducted, and of those responding, 55% were employed in a position related to their degree concentration and 32% were pursuing a graduate degree.  In addition, the PRISM early research experience served as a model adapted by two regional community colleges, who have serviced more than 100 of their students, and have received funding from NASA, NSF-CREST, and local sources.  Thus the PRISM program is impacting the scientific workforce directly through its scholars and indirectly as a model for other programs.

Data regarding the program’s goals of recruiting, retaining, and incorporating students in STEM disciplines are now summarized.  In an effort to recruit students to STEM majors, 37 of 161 (23%) of PRISM scholars were non-STEM majors when they began the program.  More than one-third of those (13 of 37) became STEM majors.  With regard to retention, 111 of the 124 scholars (89.5%) that were STEM majors when starting PRISM either continue to be STEM majors or graduated with a STEM degree.  This compares quite favorably with STEM retention rates at CSUSB, which are 67% and 53% after one and two years, respectively.  Finally, the fact mentioned above that 87% of those responding to a graduate survey are either working in a field related to their undergraduate degree or pursuing graduate studies indicates that PRISM has been effective at incorporating its scholars in scientific fields.  The PRISM program at CSUSB, then, has been successful at fulfilling its three-fold purpose of recruitment, retention and incorporation.
